facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1962, of the Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 112 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 28, 1962, of the Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 112 of 1961. C. Setalvad, Ranadeb Chaudhri, M. K. Banerjee, S.N. Andley and Rameshwer Nath, for the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant stood for election to the Orissa Legislative Assembly from the Choudwar companystituency in the district of Cuttack.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant stood for election to the Orissa Legislative Assembly from the Choudwar companystituency in the district of Cuttack. He was opposed by three persons who are the respondents before us.

facts.text: The appellant was elected from the Choudwar constituency.

anchor.surface_text: He was opposed by three persons who are the respondents before us. The appellant was elected. Then followed an election petition by respondent No. 1, Satrughna Sahu.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1, Satrughna Sahu, filed an election petition against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was elected. Then followed an election petition by respondent No. 1, Satrughna Sahu. To this election petition, the appellant as well as the other two candidates who had stood for election were made opposite parties.

facts.text: The other two candidates were made opposite parties to the election petition.

anchor.surface_text: To this election petition, the appellant as well as the other two candidates who had stood for election were made opposite parties. When the election petition came to be heard an objection was raised before the tribunal that the petition was number in accordance with s. 82

facts.text: Objection raised before the tribunal that the election petition was not in accordance with s. 82 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, and defect fatal per s. 90(3).

anchor.surface_text: When the election petition came to be heard an objection was raised before the tribunal that the petition was number in accordance with s. 82 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  43 of 1951 ,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , and that this defect was fatal to the petition in view of s. 90  3  thereof.

facts.text: The tribunal dismissed the election petition as preliminary objection.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was heard as a preliminary objection and the tribunal came to the companyclusion that as the petition was number framed in accordance with s. 82, the defect was fatal. It therefore dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Satrughna Sahu appealed to the High Court under s.116-A of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Satrughna Sahu then appealed to the High Court under s.116-A of the Act. This appeal was heard on March 5 and 6, .962, and apparently was fixed for judgment on March 8, 1962.

facts.text: The appeal was heard on March 5 and 6, 1962, fixed for judgment on March 8, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal was heard on March 5 and 6, .962, and apparently was fixed for judgment on March 8, 1962. On March 7, an application was filed by Satrughna Sahu for withdrawal of the appeal, as he did number want to prosecute it further.

facts.text: On March 7, 1962, Satrughna Sahu filed application for withdrawal of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On March 7, an application was filed by Satrughna Sahu for withdrawal of the appeal, as he did number want to prosecute it further. It was put up for companysideration on March 8, 1962, and the judgment in the main appeal, which had already been prepared for delivery, was therefore withheld pending the disposal of the withdrawal application.

facts.text: Withdrawal application put up on March 8, 1962; judgment withheld.

anchor.surface_text: It was put up for companysideration on March 8, 1962, and the judgment in the main appeal, which had already been prepared for delivery, was therefore withheld pending the disposal of the withdrawal application. The companytention on behalf of Satrughna Sahu was that he was entitled as of right to withdraw the appeal.

facts.text: Appellant supported withdrawal; other two respondents objected.

anchor.surface_text: He was supported in this by the appellant but the other two respondents objected to withdrawal and companytended that Satrughna Sahu had numberabsolute right to withdraw the appeal on the analogy of 0. XXIII, r. 1  1  of the Code of Civil Procedure

facts.text: High Court refused permission to withdraw the appeal, guided by ss.109 and 110.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that it must be guided by the principles companytained in ss. 109 and 110 of the Act when companysidering an application for withdrawal of the appeal before it. It therefore went on to companysider whether Satrughna Sahu should be given permission to withdraw the appeal and decided number to give him such permission.

facts.text: High Court ordered withdrawal application kept alive for disposal by tribunal re election petition.

anchor.surface_text: Finally it ordered that though the prayer of the appellant for withdrawal was rejected, the application for withdrawal with all the companynter-affidavits filed in opposition be kept alive for the disposal of the question of withdrawal of the election petition by the tribunal.

facts.text: On March 28, 1962, High Court set aside tribunal's dismissal and remanded the petition.

anchor.surface_text: This order was passed on March 28, 1962, and the High Court then proceeded to deliver judgment in the main appeal on the same day and the order of the election tribunal dismissing the election petition was set aside, and the petition was remanded for disposal according to law.

facts.text: Appellant applied for certificates to appeal to Supreme Court, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made two applications for certificates to appeal to this Court, which were dismissed. Thereupon he filed two petitions for special leave before this Court, which were allowed, and two appeals resulted therefrom

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave; two appeals filed, this one re withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon he filed two petitions for special leave before this Court, which were allowed, and two appeals resulted therefrom one against the judgment of the High Court in the matter of withdrawal application and the other in the matter of the main appeal.

facts.text: Section 116-A inserted in the Act in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Section 116-A was inserted in the Act in 1956, and the relevant part thereof is in these terms - ll6A. Appeals against orders of Election Tribunals- 1  An appeal shall liefromevery order made by a Tribunal under section 98 or section 99

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Satrughna Sahu had absolute right to withdraw appeal under O.XXIII r.1(1) CPC analogy.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the High Court should have allowed the application for unconditional withdrawal made by Satrughna Sahu, the appellant before it. Further the High Court in this companynection need number have referred to the affidavits filed

facts.text: Supreme Court allows the appeal, sets aside High Court order, orders appeal before HC stands withdrawn.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeal, set side the order of the High Court and in view of the unconditional application for withdrawal made by Satrughna Sahu, the appellant before the High Court, order that the appeal before the High Court should stand withdrawn.

facts.text: Hearing before Supreme Court on March 26, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Gopalakrishnan, for respondent No. 2. 1963. March 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the order of the Orissa High Court.

facts.text: Three respondents opposed the appellant in election.

anchor.surface_text: He was opposed by three persons who are the respondents before us. The appellant was elected. Then followed an election petition by respondent No. 1, Satrughna Sahu.

anchor.surface_text: Section 116-A was inserted in the Act in 1956, and the relevant part thereof is in these terms - ll6A. Appeals against orders of Election Tribunals- 1  An appeal shall liefromevery order made by a Tribunal under section 98 or section 99 to the High Court of the State in which the Tribunal is situated. The High Court shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, have the same powers, jurisdiction and authority, and follow the same procedure, with respect to an appeal under this Chapter.

issues.text: whether Satrughna Sahu who made the withdrawal application had an absolute right to withdraw the appeal on the analogy of the provision contained in O. XXIII, r. 1 (1), and therefore when the application for withdrawal was made in this case the High Court was bound to allow it and permit the withdrawal of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The first question therefore that falls for consideration is whether Satrughna Sahu who made the withdrawal application had an absolute right to withdraw the appeal on the analogy of the provision contained in XXIII, r. 1 (1), and therefore when the application for withdrawal was made in this case the High Court was bound to allow it and permit the withdrawal of the appeal.

issues.text: The question however is whether the same position [no absolute right to withdraw] applies to the withdrawal of an appeal

anchor.surface_text: This position with respect to withdrawal of an election petition is not in dispute. The question however is whether the same position applies to the withdrawal of an appeal and this brings us to the consideration of the provisions of s. 116 A of the Act, which we have already set out above.

issues.text: even if the view taken by the High Court was correct it was the duty of the High Court to consider all the matters specified in ss. 109 and 110 of the Act and decide for itself whether the application for withdrawal should be granted and it was not open to the High Court to convert the application for withdrawal of the appeal as if it was an application for withdrawal of the election petition and refer it to the election tribunal for disposal

holdings.text: the High Court has the same powers, jurisdiction and authority in the matter of withdrawal as it would have in the matter of withdrawal of an appeal from an original decree passed by a civil court within the local limits of its civil appellate jurisdiction without any limitation on such powers because of ss. 109 and 110

anchor.surface_text: So far therefore as the question of withdrawal of appeals before the High Court under Chapter IV-A is concerned, it seems to us that the High Court has the same powers, jurisdiction and authority in the matter of withdrawal as it would have in the matter of withdrawal of an appeal from an original decree passed by a civil court situated within the local limits Of its civil appellate jurisdiction without any limitation on such powers because of ss. 109 and

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.116A(2) expressly confers civil appellate powers/procedure subject only to express Act provisions; ss.109-110 in Chap.IV apply solely to petitions before tribunal/Commission, not appeals in Chap.IVA; no express extension.

holdings.text: Further the High Court in this connection need not have referred to the affidavits filed on behalf of the other two defeated candidates before it, for such affidavits were irrelevant, if Satrughna Sahu, the appellant before the High Court, was entitled to withdraw the appeal unconditionally and the High Court could not refuse such withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: Further the High Court in this connection need number have referred to the affidavits filed on behalf of the other two defeated candidates before it, for such affidavits were irrelevant, if Satrughna Sahu, the appellant before the High Court, was entitled to withdraw the appeal unconditionally and the High Court could number refuse such withdrawal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irrelevant where absolute statutory right to unconditional withdrawal exists under applicable CPC provision via s.116A(2).

holdings.text: it seems to us that the High Court was in error in treating the application for withdrawal of the appeal as if it were an application for withdrawal of an election petition under s. 109 and referring the matter to the election tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken on the first question raised before us, it is number necessary to deal with the second question, though we may add that as at present advised it seems to us that the High Court was in error in treating the application for withdrawal of the appeal as if it were an application for withdrawal of an election petition under s. 109 and referring the matter to the election tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming no absolute right, High Court bound to apply s.110 procedure itself as appellate authority under s.116A, not delegate to tribunal.

precedents.cited_proposition: public interest in election petitions and preserving purity of elections justifies special provisions restricting withdrawal

precedents.citation: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court had occasion to consider this matter in T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy  1 , in connection with an argument that the High Court had no jurisdiction to set aside the finding of the election tribunal on questions of fact arrived at on an appreciation of the evidence. In that connection this Court observed with respect to sub-s.  2  of s. 116A that it was manifest that the jurisdiction of the High Court in the disposal of appeals is similar to that it has in the disposal of appeals from original decrees.

precedents.case_name: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court under s.116A(2) has jurisdiction similar to appeals from original decrees, reopening the entire case
precedents.cited_holding: jurisdiction of the High Court in the disposal of appeals is similar to that it has in the disposal of appeals from original decrees

anchor.surface_text: In Kalyan Singh v. Rahmu  1 , it was held that where no objection had been filed by the respondent, the appellant had an absolute right to withdraw his appeal at any time before judgment. This view was followed by the Allahabad High Court in Kanhaya Lal v. Partap Chand  2 , where it was held that having regard to O. XXIII, r. 1  1  and s. 107  2  of the Code of Civil Procedure, where no cross-objection has been filed by the respondent, an appellant has the right to withdraw his appeal unconditionally, his only liability being to pay costs.

precedents.cited_proposition: appellant has absolute right to withdraw appeal unconditionally before judgment if no objection or cross-objection by respondent
precedents.cited_holding: where no objection had been filed by the respondent, the appellant had an absolute right to withdraw his appeal at any time before judgment

anchor.surface_text: This view was followed by the Allahabad High Court in Kanhaya Lal v. Partap Chand  2 , where it was held that having regard to O. XXIII, r. 1  1  and s. 107  2  of the Code of Civil Procedure, where no cross-objection has been filed by the respondent, an appellant has the right to withdraw his appeal unconditionally, his only liability being to pay costs. In Dhondo Narayan Shiralkar v. Annaji Pandurang Kokatnur  3 , it was held that an appellant is entitled as of right to withdraw his appeal, provided the respondent has not acquired any interest thereunder.

precedents.cited_proposition: appellant has right to withdraw appeal unconditionally under O. XXIII r.1(1) and s.107(2) CPC if no cross-objection
precedents.cited_holding: having regard to O. XXIII, r. 1(1) and s. 107(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure, where no cross-objection has been filed by the respondent, an appellant has the right to withdraw his appeal unconditionally

precedents.citation: Dhondo Narayan Shiralkar v. Annaji Pandurang Kokatnur 3

anchor.surface_text: In Dhondo Narayan Shiralkar v. Annaji Pandurang Kokatnur  3 , it was held that an appellant is entitled as of right to withdraw his appeal, provided the respondent has not acquired any interest thereunder. There was however difference between the Allahabad and Bombay High Courts as to whether s. 107  2  of the Code of the Civil Procedure would help an appellant in such a case.

precedents.case_name: Dhondo Narayan Shiralkar v. Annaji Pandurang Kokatnur
precedents.cited_proposition: appellant entitled as of right to withdraw appeal if respondent has not acquired interest
precedents.cited_holding: an appellant is entitled as of right to withdraw his appeal, provided the respondent has not acquired any interest thereunder
